page.title: 18Over Houses Farm, Botton
page.content: Over Houses is a modern pig farm. The pigs are Large White crossed by Landrace. There are seventy sows which can have up to sixteen piglets in a litter. Each sow has seven litters before going to the slaughter house to make meat. The piglets stay with their mother for about five weeks, then go into 'bungalows'. When the piglets are ten weeks old, they are sold to other farms. A wagon comes to collect them, but first they are weighed. There are also sheep at Over Houses. We saw them being clipped. We also saw the ferrets, kept for catching rabbits. We walked on to the fell and saw the farmer mowing grass in a field surrounded by moor and wetland. The field had been reclaimed by ploughing and draining it so that it would be good enough to silo.
